Mr. Harry Skornia
-2-
December 1, 1953
In 1951, I lo^t the Mutual Broadcasting System to accept a position with the
Office of Rent Stabilization as Chief of Radio for the Information Division, where
I wrote three weekly radio scripts entitled "The Landlord Meets the Tenant", a public
service program heard over hundreds of radio stations around the country. As Chief
of Radio for the O.R.S. it was necessary for me to maintain a constant liaison with
Members of Congress, other government agencies and commercial radio and television
stations around the country. During this tenure, I wrote the majority of speeches
for the Director of O.R.S., Tighe E. Woods, and personally accompanied him on many
of hie trips when he was scheduled to speak before various citizens groups and
organizations. 3arly in 1952, when it became apparent that the O.R.S. would be disÂ¬
solved, I joined the National Broadcasting Company in Washington, as Production
Director for News, Public Affairs and Special Events. During this time I produced
and originated many public service programs. Two of my regular network assignments
included the production of "Meet the Press" and "The American Forum of the Air".
I also originated and produced my own local radio program, known as "Washington
Controversy" which weekly took up conmunity problems of particular interest to
Washington citizens. This was a panel or forum type of program setting forth the
pros and cons of issues such as fluoridation of the city*s water supply ...Segregation
in the District of Columbia Public School System, conditions then existing in the
Municipal Hospital, Crime and Juvenile Deliquency in the District of Columbia, Traffic
Control, and similar issues of community interest.
While with NBC, I learned of the financial difficulties of the School of Nursing
in one of Washington* s largest and oldest hospitals (Qarfield Memorial) and undertook
as a personal project, not as an assl^iment from NBC, the task of helping to raise the
necessary funds to keep the School of Nursing open in order that graduate nurses might
be trained at this highly reputable, accredited school. As a direct result of my
personal contact with persons in public office and local business, radio and television
stations, newspapers, and accompanying publicity, I am very happy to be able to say that
the hospital received funds exceeding their required goal. In appreciation of my efforts,
I received a very kind letter from the Board of Directors of the Qarfield Hospital
thanking me for my participation In this worthy cause.
At the inauguration of President Eisenhower in January, 1953, I produced the entire
proceedings from the United States Capitol for NBC.
I am presently the Director of Public Relations for the Sheraton Corporation*s two
Washington hotels, the Sheraton-Park and Sheraton-Carlton (formerly Wardman Park and
Carlton) This position entails handling the advertising, promotion and publicity, as
well as extensive entertaining and general public relations for these two fine hotels.
Since the recent purchanse of these hotels by the Sheraton Corporation, it is their
plan to replace all executive personnel with men already trained in Sheraton methods
or operational procedure.
I feel that this would be an ideal time for me to return to the communications
field, inasmuch, as the move made now will be a decisive and permanent one. I have
been interested in the theory of educational television since its inception and through
my good friend Ralph Steetle, have been interested and gratified to learn of the progress
made so far in what I believe to be a crucial step forward in bringing culture, education
and practical benefits within reach of every American.
Very truly yours.
Charles Warren
Director of Public Relations
